title: 12d01 - Effect of changes in the ADV on Sec 3(s)(2) enterprises.
text:
(a)           
Enterprises not 3(s)(2) covered on
6/30/78: (Some effects of changes in the ADV under Sec 3(s)(2) on coverage of
retail or service enterprises are illustrated below. See also FOH 21a01.) (1)  A new retail or service enterprise beginning business
after 6/30/78 is not covered until its ADV reaches the applicable statutory
amount contained in Sec 3(s)(2) ($362,500 effective 1/1/82). (2)  If such an enterprise had an ADV of less than $250,000
on 6/30/78, it was not a covered Sec 3(s)(2) enterprise. This lack of coverage
under Sec 3(s)(2) continues if the enterprise never attains an ADV which would
cover it under Sec 3(s)(2) ($362,500 since 1/1/82). (3)  However, if such an enterprise’s ADV increases so that
it equals or exceeds the $362,500 ADV test currently in effect, the enterprise
must begin paying MW and OT at the time coverage becomes applicable. (4)  If the ADV later falls below $362,500, the enterprise
would not be covered and would remain so until the ADV again increases to the
$362,500 level at which time the enterprise would again be covered under Sec
3(s)(2) (b)          
Enterprises 3(s)(2) covered on
6/30/78: Some effects of changes in the ADV of a Sec 3(s)(2) enterprise which is
“grandfathered” under Sec 3(s) are illustrated below: (1)  Enterprise coverage under the grandfather clause at
the end of Sec 3(s) cannot be asserted unless the enterprise was covered on
6/30/78. The language of Sec 3(s) expressly requires that in order to be
grandfathered an enterprise must have been covered on 6/30/78. (2)  By way of illustration, if, during the period 7/1/78
to 6/30/80, a retail enterprise had an ADV of at least $275,000, and its ADV
subsequently falls below $275,000 (but remains at least $250,000), the MW
effective for that enterprise reverts to $2.65 an hour (the MW in effect on the
day before the statutory ADV increased to $275,000). This MW remains in effect
for the enterprise until its ADV falls below $250,000, or until its ADV once
again reaches a statutory ADV level which requires payment of a higher MW. This
is illustrated below:

Sec 3(s)(2) statutory ADV currently in effect:

 (3)  To further illustrate, if the ADV of a retail or
service enterprise (which was covered on 6/30/78) was $300,000 on 7/1/80, and
the enterprise became noncovered because of the increase in the statutory
standard on that date ($325,000), it would be required to continue to pay an MW
of 3.10 per hour until such time as the ADV of the enterprise met a later
statutory level ($325,000 from 7/1/80 to 12/31/81; $362,500 after 12/31/81). At
such time as the ADV of the enterprise reached the later statutory level, it would
be required to pay the MW in effect at that time ($3.35 per hour since
12/31/80). Once its ADV has risen to a later statutory level, the enterprise would
be required to continue to pay the applicable MW until such time as its ADV
falls below that level. Thereafter, it would be required to pay (1) whatever MW
was applicable “on the day before the statutory change took effect,” and (2)
proper OT. For example, if an enterprise having an ADV of $362,500 fell to an
ADV of $300,000, its applicable MW would become $3.10 an hour, which was the
statutory MW in effect on 6/30/80, the day before the statutory ADV level rose
to $325,000. If on the other hand, the ADV of the enterprise falls below $250,000,
it would cease to be covered until such time as its ADV rose to at least the
current level of $362,500. (c)           
Certain special problems which
have arisen from the application of the grandfather clause are as follows: (1)  A hotel or motel enterprise which is grandfathered
under Sec 3(s)(2) cannot pay OT based on the old partial OT exemption formerly
contained in Sec 13(b)(8) notwithstanding the fact that Sec 13(b)(8) was in
effect at the time the enterprise was grandfathered. Sec 3(s) states that a
retail or service enterprise which is grandfathered shall pay its employees in
accordance with Sec 7. There is no implication that any exemptions which were
repealed are to apply currently to grandfathered enterprises because the
exemption may have been applicable on 6/30/78, or thereafter. (2)  Retail or service enterprises which are grandfathered
under Sec 3(s)(2) cannot take a tip credit higher than that currently in effect
(40%).   There is nothing in the legislative history to indicate that the higher
tip credits which were available to employers prior to 1/1/79 or 1/1/80 are currently
to be made available to grandfathered enterprises. For example, if $3.10 continues to be the MW applicable to a
grandfathered enterprise, the employer would be entitled to a tip credit not to
exceed 40% of $3.10, that is, $1.24 per hour. (Sec 3(m), as amended, effective
1/1/80.)

(a)            Enterprises not 3(s)(2) covered on 6/30/78:

 

(Some effects of changes in the ADV under Sec 3(s)(2) on coverage of retail or service enterprises are illustrated below. See also FOH 21a01.)

 

(1)  A new retail or service enterprise beginning business after 6/30/78 is not covered until its ADV reaches the applicable statutory amount contained in Sec 3(s)(2) ($362,500 effective 1/1/82).

 

(2)  If such an enterprise had an ADV of less than $250,000 on 6/30/78, it was not a covered Sec 3(s)(2) enterprise. This lack of coverage under Sec 3(s)(2) continues if the enterprise never attains an ADV which would cover it under Sec 3(s)(2) ($362,500 since 1/1/82).

 

(3)  However, if such an enterprise’s ADV increases so that it equals or exceeds the $362,500 ADV test currently in effect, the enterprise must begin paying MW and OT at the time coverage becomes applicable.

 

(4)  If the ADV later falls below $362,500, the enterprise would not be covered and would remain so until the ADV again increases to the $362,500 level at which time the enterprise would again be covered under Sec 3(s)(2)

 

(b)           Enterprises 3(s)(2) covered on 6/30/78:

 

Some effects of changes in the ADV of a Sec 3(s)(2) enterprise which is “grandfathered” under Sec 3(s) are illustrated below:

 

(1)  Enterprise coverage under the grandfather clause at the end of Sec 3(s) cannot be asserted unless the enterprise was covered on 6/30/78. The language of Sec 3(s) expressly requires that in order to be grandfathered an enterprise must have been covered on 6/30/78.

 

(2)  By way of illustration, if, during the period 7/1/78 to 6/30/80, a retail enterprise had an ADV of at least $275,000, and its ADV subsequently falls below $275,000 (but remains at least $250,000), the MW effective for that enterprise reverts to $2.65 an hour (the MW in effect on the day before the statutory ADV increased to $275,000). This MW remains in effect for the enterprise until its ADV falls below $250,000, or until its ADV once again reaches a statutory ADV level which requires payment of a higher MW. This is illustrated below:

(3)  To further illustrate, if the ADV of a retail or service enterprise (which was covered on 6/30/78) was $300,000 on 7/1/80, and the enterprise became noncovered because of the increase in the statutory standard on that date ($325,000), it would be required to continue to pay an MW of 3.10 per hour until such time as the ADV of the enterprise met a later statutory level ($325,000 from 7/1/80 to 12/31/81; $362,500 after 12/31/81). At such time as the ADV of the enterprise reached the later statutory level, it would be required to pay the MW in effect at that time ($3.35 per hour since 12/31/80).

 

Once its ADV has risen to a later statutory level, the enterprise would be required to continue to pay the applicable MW until such time as its ADV falls below that level. Thereafter, it would be required to pay (1) whatever MW was applicable “on the day before the statutory change took effect,” and (2) proper OT. For example, if an enterprise having an ADV of $362,500 fell to an ADV of $300,000, its applicable MW would become $3.10 an hour, which was the statutory MW in effect on 6/30/80, the day before the statutory ADV level rose to $325,000.

 

If on the other hand, the ADV of the enterprise falls below $250,000, it would cease to be covered until such time as its ADV rose to at least the current level of $362,500.

 

(c)            Certain special problems which have arisen from the application of the grandfather clause are as follows:

 

(1)  A hotel or motel enterprise which is grandfathered under Sec 3(s)(2) cannot pay OT based on the old partial OT exemption formerly contained in Sec 13(b)(8) notwithstanding the fact that Sec 13(b)(8) was in effect at the time the enterprise was grandfathered. Sec 3(s) states that a retail or service enterprise which is grandfathered shall pay its employees in accordance with Sec 7. There is no implication that any exemptions which were repealed are to apply currently to grandfathered enterprises because the exemption may have been applicable on 6/30/78, or thereafter.

 

(2)  Retail or service enterprises which are grandfathered under Sec 3(s)(2) cannot take a tip credit higher than that currently in effect (40%). 

 

There is nothing in the legislative history to indicate that the higher tip credits which were available to employers prior to 1/1/79 or 1/1/80 are currently to be made available to grandfathered enterprises.

 

For example, if $3.10 continues to be the MW applicable to a grandfathered enterprise, the employer would be entitled to a tip credit not to exceed 40% of $3.10, that is, $1.24 per hour. (Sec 3(m), as amended, effective 1/1/80.)
